thread.title: EAA chancellor Veronica Conforme gets new job
thread.title_full: EAA chancellor Veronica Conforme gets new job

author: Detroit Free Press
title: EAA chancellor Veronica Conforme gets new job
text:
EAA chancellor Veronica Conforme gets new job Conforme has been the chancellor for the Education Achievement Authority for three years Post to Facebook EAA chancellor Veronica Conforme gets new job Conforme has been the chancellor for the Education Achievement Authority for three years  //on.freep.com/2lnkfdy   EAA chancellor Veronica Conforme gets new job Lori Higgins , Detroit Free Press Published 5:24   12   (Photo: Detroit Free Press file) Buy Photo   
Veronica Conforme, the chancellor of the soon-to-be-defunct Education Achievement Authority, was hired this week to lead a nonprofit organization that works to turn around chronically failing schools in Massachusetts. 
Conforme has been the EAA chancellor for three years, taking over the controversial system at a time when questions were being raised about spending and lackluster improvement in results on state exams. 
The EAA opened in 2012 as a state reform district for the worst-performing schools in the state, though it has only taken on Detroit schools. 
She will be the CEO of the UP Education Network, a nonprofit created in 2010 in Massachusetts to "rapidly transform chronically underperforming district schools into extraordinary schools," according to the organization's web site. 
Read more: EAA to pay $2.25 million to Detroit district, return schools by July 
"Veronica Conforme is uniquely qualified to lead UP Education Network through its transition from a Boston-based startup to a statewide partner in school turnaround work," Mitchell Chester, commissioner of elementary and secondary education in Massachusetts, said in a press release from the organization that was provided by the EAA this afternoon. 
The EAA will disband after the end of this school year, and the schools that are part of the system will be returned to the Detroit Public Schools Community District. 
Conforme said in a letter to her team this morning that she intends to stay with the EAA until the transition of the schools back to the Detroit district. 
"Today, I am even more energized and deeply committed to ensuring an equitable transition for our schools. I will tirelessly advocate for you and the work you do and commit to you that I will remain at the EAA until June 30." 
She said she has "absolutely loved my time here. Despite feeling like we did not have enough time together, I know one thing for sure: together, we have made a lasting impact on thousands of children." 
In her letter, Conforme cited improved results on the Michigan Student Test of Educational Progress, noting that on average schools saw more improvement than the statewide average. 
Contact Lori Higgins: 313-222-6651, lhiggins@freepress.com or @LoriAHiggins
